{{For|the book by the same author|Savage Love: Straight Answers from America's Most Popular Sex Columnist}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2017}} [[File:Dan Savage Provided.jpg|thumb|right|[[Dan Savage]] (2005)]] '''Savage Love''' is a syndicated sex-[[advice column]] by [[Dan Savage]]. The column appears weekly in several dozen newspapers, mainly free newspapers in the US and Canada, but also newspapers in Europe and Asia. It started in 1991 with the first issue of the [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]] weekly newspaper ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]''.
Since October 2006, Savage has also recorded the ''Savage Lovecast'', a weekly [[podcast]] version of the column, featuring telephone advice sessions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://podcasts.thestranger.com/savagelove/archives.php#a029910 |title=Dan Savage |publisher=Podcasts.thestranger.com |accessdate=March 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206090407/http://podcasts.thestranger.com/savagelove/archives.php#a029910 |archivedate=December 6, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Podcasts are released every Tuesday.
Since 2002, he has written the column at [[Eppie Lederer]]'s desk, which he, a "lifelong fan" of her [[Ann Landers]] column, bought at auction after the noted advice columnist died.<ref name="savage desk">{{cite news |url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/SavageLove?oid=12738 |title=Ann Advises On |date=December 5, 2002 |first=Dan |last=Savage |newspaper=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |accessdate=September 20, 2008}}</ref>
== History == In 1991, Savage was living in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], and working as a manager at a local video store that specialized in independent film titles.<ref name="GLBTQ Bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/savage_d.html |title=GLBTQ Literature: Dan Savage |publisher=GLBTQ.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604104320/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/savage_d.html |archivedate=June 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref> There, he befriended Tim Keck, co-founder of ''[[The Onion]]'', who announced that he was moving to [[Seattle]] to help start an alternative weekly newspaper titled ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]''.<ref name="GLBTQ Bio" /> Savage "made the offhand comment that forever altered [his] life: 'Make sure your paper has an advice column – everybody claims to hate 'em, but everybody seems to read 'em'."<ref>Dan Savage, Introduction, ''Savage Love: Straight Answers from America's Most Popular Sex Columnist'' (New York: Plume, 1998), p. 2.</ref> He typed up a sample column, and to his surprise Keck offered him the job.<ref name=AV-club>[http://www.avclub.com/content/node/45150 Dan Savage interviewed by Tasha Robinson], ''The A.V. Club'', February 8, 2006.</ref><ref>Dan Savage, Introduction, ''Savage Love: Straight Answers from America's Most Popular Sex Columnist'', op. cit., pp. 1–5.</ref>
Savage stated in a February 2006 interview in ''The Onion''{{'}}s ''[[The A.V. Club|A.V. Club]]'' (which publishes his column) that he began the column with the express purpose of providing mocking advice to heterosexuals, since most straight advice columnists were "clueless" when responding to letters from gay people.<ref name=AV-club />
== Language == === Recapture of offensive words === For the first six years of the column, Savage had his readers address him with "Hey, [[Faggot (slang)|faggot]]", as a comment on previous efforts to [[Reclaimed word|recapture offensive words]]. He was criticized for this by some gay activists.
=== Neologisms === During the run of Savage Love, Savage has popularized several [[neologism]]s. He has also debunked several sexual neologisms for violent sex acts, including the "[[donkey punch]]", the "[[Pirate (sexual slang)|pirate]]" and the "[[Hot Karl (slang)|hot Karl]]", concluding "They're all fictions."<ref name="savage2004">{{cite news |title=No Shit? |author=Dan Savage |url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=20179&mode=print |newspaper=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |date=December 23–29, 2004 |accessdate=February 16, 2012}}</ref>
==== Campsite rule ==== In any relationship, but particularly those with a large difference of age or experience between the partners, the older or more experienced partner has the responsibility to leave the younger or less experienced partner in at least as good a state (emotionally and physically) as before the relationship. The "campsite rule" includes things like leaving the younger or less experienced partner with no [[Sexually transmitted disease|STDs]], no unwanted pregnancies, and not overburdening them with emotional and sexual baggage.<ref>{{cite news |last=Q |first=Dan |title=Savage Love Readers Talk About the Campsite Rule |pages= |newspaper=Scatmania |location= |date=May 14, 2008 |url=http://www.scatmania.org/2008/05/14/campsite/ |accessdate=December 11, 2013}}</ref>
==== Tea and Sympathy rule ==== Shortly after a 2009 scandal in [[Portland, Oregon]], involving openly gay mayor [[Sam Adams (Oregon politician)|Sam Adams]] and Beau Breedlove, who had allegedly turned 18 almost immediately before the two began a sexual relationship, Savage created a companion rule to the "campsite rule", now known as the "Tea and Sympathy rule". The rule is a reference to a line in the [[Tea and Sympathy (play)|play of the same name]], in which a much older woman asks of a high-school-age boy, right before having sex with him: "Years from now, when you talk about this – and you will – be kind."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/19/movies/19kerr.html?pagewanted=print Deborah Kerr, Actress Known for Genteel Grace and a Sexy Beach Kiss, Dies at 86] – ''The New York Times''</ref> Savage claimed in an article in ''[[The Portland Mercury]]'' that, while Adams followed the "campsite rule" – Breedlove did not claim that Adams had given him any diseases or caused him emotional trauma, and in fact still refers to Adams as a friend – Breedlove violated the "Tea and Sympathy" rule by making public statements that he knew could ruin Adams's career.<ref>[http://www.portlandmercury.com/portland/the-tea-and-sympathy-rule/Content?oid=1089470 The Tea and Sympathy Rule] ''Portland Mercury''</ref>
==== Monogamish ==== In a July 20, 2011 column, Savage coined the term "monogamish". The term describes couples who are perceived to be [[monogamy|monogamous]], who are "mostly" monogamous, but who are not 100% monogamous. Such couples have an understanding that allows for some amount of sexual contact outside the relationship.<ref name=monogamish>{{cite web |url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/SavageLove?oid=9125045 |title=Savage Love: Monogamish |last=Savage |first=Dan |date= July 20, 2011 |work=The Stranger |accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref> Savage believes that of all the couples people think are 100% monogamous, a lot of them are more "monogamish" than people realize. The term has since seen mainstream use.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://time.com/2998792/satisfaction-monogamish-infidelity-married/ |title=Are You 'Monogamish'? A New Survey Says Lots of Couples Are |last=Luscombe |first=Belinda |date= July 17, 2014 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/03/magazine/infidelity-will-keep-us-together.html |title=Married, with Infidelities |last=Oppenheimer |first=Mark |date= June 3, 2011 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref>
==== Pegging ==== {{Main|Pegging (sexual practice)}} In 2001, Savage challenged readers of his column to coin a name for the sex act in which a woman uses a strap-on [[dildo]] to perform [[anal sex]] on her male partner. After multiple nominations and a reader vote, the verb "[[pegging (sexual practice)|peg]]" was chosen, with a 43% [[Plurality (voting)|plurality]] over runners-up "bob" and "punt".<ref>Dan Savage, [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/SavageLove?oid=7730 We Have a Winner!]. ''The Stranger'', June 21, 2001. Accessed April 7, 2013.<!--See talk page for any thoughts.--></ref>
==== Santorum ==== {{Main|Campaign for the neologism "santorum"|Rick Santorum's views on homosexuality}} Savage reacted strongly to statements made about homosexuality by former [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] [[Rick Santorum]] in an April 2003 interview with the [[Associated Press]].<ref name=USATodayApril232003>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2003-04-23-santorum-excerpt_x.htm |title=Excerpt from Santorum interview |newspaper=USA Today |issn=0734-7456 |date=April 23, 2003}}</ref> Santorum included gay sex as a form of deviant sexual behavior, along with incest, [[polygamy]], and bestiality, that he said threatens society and the family; he said he believed consenting adults do not have a [[United States Constitution|constitutional]] [[right to privacy]] with respect to sexual acts.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2003-04-23-santorum-excerpt_x.htm Excerpt from Santorum in an interview]: "...if the Supreme Court says that you have the right to consensual sex within your home, then you have the right to bigamy, ... [y]ou have the right to anything. Does that undermine the fabric of our society? I would argue yes, it does.", ''[[USA Today]]'', April 23, 2003</ref> Savage invited his readers to create a sex-related definition for "santorum" to "memorialize the Santorum scandal [...] by attaching his name to a sex act that would make his big, white teeth fall out of his big, empty head."<ref>Savage, Dan. [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/SavageLove?oid=14267 "Bill, Ashton, Rick"], ''The Stranger'', May 15, 2003.</ref> The winning definition was "the frothy mixture of lube and fecal matter that is sometimes the byproduct of anal sex."<ref>Savage, Dan. [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/SavageLove?oid=14566 "Gas Huffer"], ''The Stranger'', June 12, 2003.</ref> Savage set up a website to spread the term, inviting bloggers and others to link to it, which caused it to rise to the top of a Google search for Santorum's name.<ref>Mencimer, Stephanie. [http://motherjones.com/politics/2010/08/rick-santorum-google-problem-dan-savage "Rick Santorum's Anal Sex Problem"], ''Mother Jones'', September/October 2010.</ref>
==== Lifting luggage ==== {{anchor|Lifing Luggage|reason=Old, over-capitalized heading name, may be linked to.}} Following the [[George Rekers#"Rent boy" allegations|"rent boy" allegations]] regarding [[George Rekers]], who has widely promoted [[aversion therapy]], Dan Savage, along with others including [[Stephen Colbert]],<ref>"Colbert Rips Anti-Gay Activist, Throws 'Rentboy' Dance Party" {{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/05/06/colbert-rips-anti-gay-act_n_565763.html| title = Colbert Rips Anti-Gay Activist, Throws 'Rentboy' Dance Party |publisher=The Huffington Post | first=Dan| last=Abramson| date=May 6, 2010 |accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> promoted the use of the idiom "to lift [some]one's luggage", meaning to supply sexual pleasure to, or derive it from, one's partner. This originated from Rekers who, when outed, insisted he had hired the escort only to assist him with lifting his luggage.<ref name="timesonline">{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article7117037.ece | location=London | work=The Times | first1=Giles | last1=Whittell |title=Baptist minister 'took ten-day holiday with male prostitute' |date=May 6, 2010}}</ref> Rekers also claimed he "spent a great deal of time sharing scientific information on the desirability of abandoning homosexual intercourse" and "shared the gospel of Jesus Christ with him in great detail".<ref name="timesonline" />
Originally Savage suggested that "lifting my luggage" refer to listening to the speaker expound on the "desirability" of converting oneself from homosexual to heterosexual. Later, after several political humorists started employing "lifting your luggage" as an implicit or explicit reference to various sexual acts,<ref>"'Lift My Luggage' Is the New 'Hiking the Appalachian Trail'" by Daniel Kurtzman {{cite web|url=http://politicalhumor.about.com/b/2010/05/06/lift-my-luggage-is-the-new-hiking-the-appalachian-trail.htm| title=About.com --Daniel Kurtzman's Political Humor Blog|accessdate=October 21, 2010}}</ref> Savage suggested that "whatever lifts your luggage" supplant "whatever floats your boat" in common parlance.
==== Saddlebacking ==== In 2009, after a controversy involving the [[Saddleback Church]], the column defined "saddlebacking" as "the phenomenon of Christian teens engaging in unprotected anal sex in order to preserve their virginities".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/SavageLove?oid=1031968|title=Savage Love|work=The Stranger}}</ref>
==== Leotarded ==== After receiving criticism for use of the word "retarded"—considered by many to be an offensive slur against those with intellectual disabilities—Savage suggested "leotarded" as an alternative, because "leotard" rhymes with "retard".
=== Initialisations === ==== GGG ==== Dan Savage coined the abbreviation "GGG".<ref name="walczak">Ken Walczak, [http://www.good.is/posts/the-ggg-cocktail-a-non-vanilla-drink-inspired-by-dan-savage "The GGG Cocktail"], www.good.is, May 9, 2012 (accessed December 26, 2012) ("Dan is best known for two things: his advice that partners in any relationship strive to be Good, Giving, and Game (GGG) and ...").</ref><ref name="Salon1">{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2012/09/12/science_proves_it_dan_savage_is_right/|title=Science proves it: Dan Savage is right|author=DebHerbenick|publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]}}</ref> It stands for "good, giving, and game", and it means one should strive to be ''good'' in bed, ''giving'' "equal time and equal pleasure" to one's partner, and ''game'' "for anything – within reason".<ref name="Salon1" /><ref>Dan Savage, [http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/SavageLove?oid=167448 Wrong & Right], ''The Stranger'' March 1, 2007 (accessed December 26, 2012).</ref> The term has inspired the "How GGG Are You? Test" on the popular Internet dating site [[OkCupid]], and the invention of a [[cocktail]].<ref name="walczak" />
==== DTMFA ==== "Dump the mother-fucker already", used at a closing of a response to indicate that acting immediately to end the writer's abusive or worthless relationship is advised.
==== ITMFA ==== A reader of Savage Love suggested the initialisation ITMFA, a take on DTMFA, meaning "Impeach the Motherfucker Already!" The initialisation was coined in reference to the [[presidency of George W. Bush]] in 2006, but was reintroduced in 2017 in reaction to the [[presidency of Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestranger.com/slog/2017/01/25/24822658/impeach-the-motherfucker-already|title=Impeach the Motherfucker Already!|work=The Stranger}}</ref>
==== CPOS ==== "Cheating piece of shit", said of a cheater, but usually reserved for one who is chronic or abusive/passive-aggressive about it.
==== HTH ==== "How'd that happen?", a mock-incredulous reply to those to who write in and say they had certain (often sexual) things "happen to" them, as if they had no part or say in the incident, when they clearly did.
=== Usage === Savage objected to use of the term "pussy" as an insult, saying that vaginas were wonderful, popping out babies, and proposed "[[scrotum]]", plural "scrota", as an insult.

'''Somaesthetics''' is an interdisciplinary field of inquiry aimed at promoting and integrating the theoretical, empirical and practical disciplines related to bodily perception, performance and presentation. == Etymology == The term ‘somaesthetics’ was coined by the American pragmatist philosopher [[Richard Shusterman]] in 1996 through the compounding of “soma”, an expression derived from the Greek word for body, and “[[aesthetics]]”, a word derived from the Greek ''aesthesis'', meaning ‘sensory perception’.While Shusterman was the first to use 'somaesthetics' in reference to a philosophical discipline, a form of the term had been in use within the neurological sciences as an alternate label for the somatosensory cortex, i.e. the somaesthetic cortex. In American English, this alternate label is usually rendered with a different spelling: somesthetic. Shusterman has reported in a number of his works that he chose ‘soma’ over more familiar terms “to avoid problematic associations of body (which can be a lifeless, mindless thing) and flesh (which designates only the fleshly parts of the body and is strongly associated with Christian notions of sin)” and to emphasize that the project “concerns the lived, sentient, purposive body rather than merely a physical body”.{{cite web|last1=Shusterman|first1=Richard|title=Somaesthetics|url=https://www.interaction-design.org/encyclopedia/somaesthetics.html|website=Encyclopedia of Human-Computer Interaction|publisher=Interaction Design Foundation|accessdate=3 August 2015}} As an amalgamation, ‘somaesthetics’ “implies a project of appreciating and cultivating the body not only as an object that externally displays beauty, sublimity, grace, and other aesthetic qualities, but also as a subjectivity that perceives these qualities and that experiences attendant aesthetic pleasures somatically”. == Origin and development == Somaesthetics as a research project initially arose from the work of Richard Shusterman during the mid-1990s in response to what he perceived as needed developments within his two principal modes of inquiry: pragmatist aesthetics and philosophy as an embodied art of living. While pragmatist aesthetics, according to Shusterman, advocates for more active and creative engagement than traditional aesthetics, he believed it should also recognize that artistic, practical and political action requires humanity’s primary tool, the body, and that such action could be improved partly by improving this instrument.{{cite web|last1=Shusterman|first1=Richard|title=Somaesthetics|url=https://www.interaction-design.org/encyclopedia/somaesthetics.html|website=Encyclopedia of Human-Computer Interaction|publisher=Interaction Design Foundation|accessdate=4 August 2015}} In the same way, the philosophical life could be improved through greater mastery of the soma -- our medium of living. He moreover lamented the reduction of aesthetics (as well as philosophy itself) from “a noble art of living into a minor, specialized university discipline” narrowly concerned with beauty and fine art.{{cite journal|last1=Shusterman|first1=Richard|title=Somaesthetics: A Disciplinary Proposal|journal=Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism|date=Summer 1999|volume=57|issue=3|page=301|url=http://www.staff.amu.edu.pl/~ewa/Somaesthetics.pdf|accessdate=4 August 2015}} Shusterman thus argued for the revival of “[[Alexander Gottlieb Baumgarten|Baumgarten]]’s idea of aesthetics as a life-improving cognitive discipline that extends far beyond questions of beauty and fine arts and that involves both theory and practical exercise” and for an end to “the neglect of the body that Baumgarten disastrously introduced into aesthetics”.{{cite journal|last1=ibid.}} As proposed, Shusterman’s project of somaesthetics would restore “the soma — the living, sentient, purposive body — as the indispensable medium for all perception". Such heightening of somatic consciousness would not only enhance artistic appreciation and creation, but increase the perceptual awareness of meanings and feelings that have the potential to elevate everyday experience into an art of living. Shusterman proposed three fundamental dimensions of his emerging field:
• Analytic somaesthetics, as the most theoretically-oriented of the three, “describes the basic nature of bodily perceptions and practices and also of their function in our knowledge and construction of reality”.{{cite journal|last1=Shusterman|first1=Richard|title=Somaesthetics: A Disciplinary Proposal|journal=Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism|date=Summer 1999|volume=57|issue=3|page=304|url=http://www.staff.amu.edu.pl/~ewa/Somaesthetics.pdf|accessdate=4 August 2015}}
• Pragmatic somaesthetics presupposes the analytic dimension and “has a distinctly normative, prescriptive character – by proposing specific methods of somatic improvement and engaging in their comparative critique”.{{cite journal|last1=Shusterman|first1=Richard|title=Somaesthetics: A Disciplinary Proposal|journal=Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism|date=Summer 1999|volume=57|issue=3|pages=304–305|url=http://www.staff.amu.edu.pl/~ewa/Somaesthetics.pdf|accessdate=4 August 2015}}
• Practical somaesthetics focuses on practicing somatic care “through intelligently disciplined body work aimed at somatic self-improvement (whether in a representational, experiential, or performative mode)".{{cite journal|last1=Shusterman|first1=Richard|title=Somaesthetics: A Disciplinary Proposal|journal=Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism|date=Summer 1999|volume=57|issue=3|page=307|url=http://www.staff.amu.edu.pl/~ewa/Somaesthetics.pdf|accessdate=4 August 2015}} Over the past two decades, somaesthetics has become a truly interdisciplinary endeavor. Originally conceived by Shusterman as being under the umbrella of [[philosophy]], or perhaps even a branch of [[aesthetics]], somaesthetics has evolved into an “open field for collaborative, interdisciplinary, and transcultural inquiry” with applications “ranging from the arts, product design, and politics to fashion, health, sports, martial arts, and the use of hallucinogenic drugs in education”.{{cite web|last1=Shusterman|first1=Richard|title=Somaesthetics|url=https://www.interaction-design.org/encyclopedia/somaesthetics.html#heading_Genealogy_and_Emergence_page_107797|website=Encyclopedia of Human-Computer Interaction|publisher=Interaction Design Foundation|accessdate=4 August 2015}} == Further reading == • Heyes, Cressida J. ''Self transformations: Foucault, Ethics, and Normalized Bodies''. Oxford; New York: Oxford University Press, 2007.
• Höök, Kristina, Anna Ståhl, Martin Jonsson, Johanna Mercurio, Anna Karlsson, and Eva-Carin Banka Johnson. “Somaesthetic Design.” ''Interactions'' 22.4 (2015): 26-33.
• Jay, Martin. “Somaesthetics and Democracy: Dewey and Contemporary Body Art,” in Martin Jay, ''Refractions of Violence'' (New York: Routledge, 2003).
• Jolles, Marjorie. “Between Embodied Subjects and Objects: Narrative Somaesthetics.” ''Hypatia'' 27:2 (2012): 301–318.
• Mullis, Eric C. “Performative Somaesthetics: Principles and Scope.” ''Journal of Aesthetic Education'', 40.4 (2006): 104-117.
• Shusterman, Richard. ''Body Consciousness: A Philosophy of Mindfulness and Somaesthetics''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2008.
• Shusterman, Richard. ''Thinking through the Body: Essays in Somaesthetics''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2012.
• Tedesco, Salvatore. “Somaesthetics as a Discipline Between Pragmatist Philosophy and Philosophical Anthropology.” ''Pragmatism Today: The Journal of the Central-European Pragmatist Forum'' 3.2 (Winter 2012): 6-12.
• Terry-Fritsch, Allie. “Performing the Renaissance Body and Mind: Somaesthetic Style and Devotional Practice at the Sacro Monte di Varallo.” ''Open Arts Journal'' 4 (2015): 111-132.
• Turner, Bryan. “Somaesthetics and the Critique of Cartesian Dualism.” ''Body & Society'' 14.3 (2008): 129-133. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://journals.aau.dk/index.php/JOS/ Journal of Somaesthetics] * [http://www.brill.com/studies-somaesthetics Studies in Somaesthetics book series] * [http://www.fau.edu/bodymindculture/ Center for Body, Mind, and Culture at FAU] * [http://www.pragmatismtoday.eu/index.php?id=2012winter2 Symposium on Somaesthetics in ''Pragmatism Today''] [[Category:Applied philosophy]] [[Category:Philosophy by topic]]

{{unreferenced|date=September 2016}} '''TROFREC''', or (Tropical Feed Resources Research and Development Center), is a research centers at the Faculty of Agriculture, [[Khon Kaen University]], Thailand.
TROFREC's mandate is to undertake research work in areas of animal feed resources, feeding systems, technology transfers in related areas, as well as human resources development ranging from farmers to technical/academic and higher-learning personnel.
Research projects include the uses of [[urea-treated rice straw]], [[cassava hay]], [[cass-soy pellet]], [[high-quality feed block]], [[cassava hay-urea pellet]], [[cass-bann]], rumen manipulation and rumen microbes; water buffalo rumen ecology, herbs uses in non-ruminants and ruminants, and feeding systems based on agricultural crop-residues, by-products and total mixed rations.
TROFREC is headed by its director, Professor Dr [[Metha Wanapat]].
== External links == [http://home.kku.ac.th/trofrec TROFREC website]

The Virginia Tech Institute for Policy and Governance is an [[entrepreneurial]], [[interdisciplinary]] community of collaborating [[Faculty (academic staff)|faculty]], staff and [[students]] that conducts governance-related [[research]], learning and engagement efforts concerning significant public challenges.<ref>[http://www.ipg.vt.edu/VTIPG/About%20Us/index.html About the Institute]</ref>
== Introduction== Virginia Tech's Institute for Policy and Governance (IPG) is a major research and outreach body for the [[Commonwealth of Virginia]] and local governments within the state and nonprofit/civil society organizations across the [[globe]]. IPG seeks to improve the response of government, businesses, and nonprofit institutions to various policy challenges such as healthcare, social services, regional [[infrastructure]], and workforce and [[economic development]]. To accomplish these goals, IPG engages in an active program of policy research, dissemination, implementation, and technical assistance involving faculty and [[graduate student]]s. IPG exercises outreach to state agencies, local governments, and the community in the form of seminars, internships, and volunteer service.
==Functions== * Design evaluation studies * Conduct needs assessments and implementation studies * Perform program assessment * Develop in-person, telephone, and e-mail surveys * Conduct focus groups and interviews * Foster federal/state/local relationship<ref>[http://www.ipg.vt.edu/VTIPG/About%20Us/index.html About the functions]</ref>
==See also== *[[Virginia Tech]] *[[Virginia Tech School of Public and International Affairs]]

The '''William I. Fine Theoretical Physics Institute''' is a research institute in the [[University of Minnesota College of Science and Engineering]]. FTPI was largely the work of physics Professor Emeritus, [[Stephen Gasiorowicz]] and University alumnus and Twin-Cities real-estate developer William I. Fine.<ref>[http://issuu.com/inventingtomorrow/docs/v32_n2_spring_2008_inventing_tomorrow UMN, CSE Inventing Tomorrow, Spring/Summer 2008, Vol. 32, 2., P.32-33]</ref> The Institute officially came into existence in January 1987.<ref>[http://www.symmetrymagazine.org/article/august-2007/donors-big-dream Symmetry Magazine, August 2007]</ref> FTPI faculty consists of seven permanent members: [[Alex Kamenev]], [[Keith Olive]], [[Mikhail Shifman]], [[Boris Shklovskii]], [[Arkady Vainshtein]], [[Mikhail Voloshin]], and [[Andrey V. Chubukov]] as well as postdoctoral and graduate students.<ref>[http://www.ftpi.umn.edu/people/ William I. Fine Theoretical Physics Institute People]</ref>
The '''William I. Fine Theoretical Physics Institute''' has on Oversight Committee consisting of 8 members.<ref>[http://www.ftpi.umn.edu/people/oscomm.html William I. Fine Theoretical Physics Institute People OSC]</ref> The Oversight Committee is essentially a board of directors that make decisions concerning the staffing and budgeting of the Institute.<ref>[http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/magazine/physicstoday/article/44/2/10.1063/1.2809991 Physics Today, February 1991]</ref>
== Outreach ==
'''The Misel Family Lecture Series'''
The Irving and Edythe Misel Family Lecture Series, hosted by FTPI, invites physicists from around the world to the University of Minnesota to discuss physics with the general public. It is funded by a generous gift from the Edythe and Irving Misel family. The list of the Misel Lecturers to date is: 2006: [[Frank Wilczek]] (2004 Nobel Prize in Physics), 2007: [[Leo Kadanoff]] (1980 Wolf Prize), 2008: [[Jim Peebles]] (1982 Heineman Prize), 2009: [[Helen Quinn]] (2000 Dirac Medal), 2010: [[N. David Mermin]] (2010 Majorana Prize), 2011: [[Roger Blandford]] (1998 Heineman Prize), 2012: [[John Ellis (physicist)|John Ellis]] (2005 Dirac Medal), 2013: [[Eric Cornell]] (2001 Nobel Prize in Physics), 2014: [[Andrei Linde]] (2012 Fundamental Physics Prize), 2015: [[Joseph Polchinski]] (2008 [[Dirac Medal]] and 2017 [[Fundamental Physics Prize]]), 2016: [[John Preskill]] (member of the [[National Academy of Science]]): 2017: [[Wendy Freedman]] (2016 [[Dannie Heineman Prize for Astrophysics]]).<ref>[http://www.ftpi.umn.edu/misel/ William I. Fine Theoretical Physics Institute Misel]</ref>
'''Visitor Program'''
FTPI has a worldwide reach. The Institute has hosted over 800 individual researchers, from institutions in more than 18 different countries, for working visits of one day to six months.<ref>[http://issuu.com/inventingtomorrow/docs/v32_n2_spring_2008_inventing_tomorrow UMN, CSE Inventing Tomorrow, Spring/Summer 2008, Vol. 32, 2., P.32-33]</ref>
'''Workshops'''
FTPI hosts up to three workshops per year for physicists from around the world.<ref>[http://www.ftpi.umn.edu/workshops/ William I. Fine Theoretical Physics Institute Workshops]</ref> This includes the 2013 CAQCD meeting which was special because it was the tenth meeting in the series. The proceedings of the previous conferences – they are held biannually – reveal the developments of QCD and related theories from the early 1990s.<ref>[http://cerncourier.com/cws/article/cern/54389/2 CERN Courier, 2013]</ref> As well as a workshop in October 2000 celebrating 30 years of supersymmetry.<ref>[http://cerncourier.com/cws/article/cern/28388 CERN Courier, 2001]</ref>
== Awards ==
Current and former faculty members of FTPI have been honored with a number of prizes and awards. Keith Olive is a current Distinguished McKnight University Professor of Physics<ref>[http://www.scholarswalk.umn.edu/awards/mcknight/mcknight_distinguished.html UMN Distinguished McKnight University Professor]</ref> and was awarded the 2018 [[Hans Bethe Prize]]. <ref>[https://www.aps.org/programs/honors/prizes/prizerecipient.cfm?last_nm=Olive&first_nm=Keith&year=2018 APS Prizes and Awards]</ref> Former faculty, Leonid Glazman was a McKnight Presidential Endowed Chair.<ref>[http://www.ftpi.umn.edu/about/ About FTPI]</ref> Boris Shklovskii is the recipient of the 1986 Landau Award <ref>[http://www.physics.umn.edu/about/awards.html UMN Physics Awards]</ref> [[Arkady Vainshtein]] and [[Mikhail Shifman]] were awarded the 2016 [[Dirac Medal and Prize]]. <ref> [https://www.ictp.it/about-ictp/prizes-awards/the-dirac-medal/the-medallists/dirac-medallists-2016.aspx Dirac Medallists 2016]</ref>
Three faculty members have been awarded the [[Sakurai Prize]]: [[Arkady Vainshtein]] (1999), [[Mikhail Shifman]] (1999), and [[Mikhail Voloshin]] (2001).<ref>[http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/prizes/sakurai.cfm APS Sakurai Prize ]</ref> [[Arkady Vainshtein]] (2005) and [[Mikhail Shifman]] (2013) received the [[Pomeranchuk Prize]].<ref>[http://www.itep.ru/eng/?pprize.html ITEP Pomeranchuk Prize ]</ref> [[Mikhail Shifman]] was honored with the [[Lilienfeld Prize]] (2006),<ref>[http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/prizes/lilienfeld.cfm APS Lilienfeld Prize ]</ref> and elected as Laureate of Les Chaires Internacionales de Recherche Blaise Pascal(2007)<ref>[http://www.physics.umn.edu/about/awards.html UMN Physics Awards ]</ref> Former member Anatoly Larkin was awarded the [[Fritz London Memorial Prize]] in Low Temperature Physics (1990),<ref>[http://www.phy.duke.edu/~hm/flondonprizeawards.html Duke Physics Fritz London Memorial Prize]</ref> the Hewlett Packard Europhysics Prize (1993),<ref>[http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/prizes/prizerecipient.cfm?first_nm=Anatoly&last_nm=Larkin&year=2002 APS Physics]</ref> the [[Lars Onsager Prize]] in Theoretical Statistical Physics (2002)<ref>[http://www.aps.org/programs/honors/prizes/onsager.cfm APS Lars Onsager Prize]</ref> as well as the Bardeen Prize for Superconductivity (2004).<ref>[http://www.m2s-2012.org/john-bardeen-prize/ Bardeen Prize]</ref>
== Funding == The William I. Fine Theoretical Physics Institute is financed from a combination of private and University funds.<ref>[http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/magazine/physicstoday/article/40/2/10.1063/1.2819908 Physics Today February 1987]</ref> In the world of fundamental-science research institutes, FTPI is, for its part, something of an oddity. While most such organizations are large, National Science Foundation-funded enterprises, Minnesota's FTPI was created in large part out of the generosity of a single private donor, and it is dedicated to the research efforts of its members.<ref>[http://business.highbeam.com/137256/article-1G1-55128657/worlds-apart Mpls-St. Paul Magazine 1999]</ref>
The [[United States Department of Energy]] ER40823 grant is mutually submitted between the Department of Physics at the [[University of Minnesota]] and FTPI. This grant is entitled "Experimental and Theoretical High Energy Physics" and helps to support faculty and postdoctoral salaries.<ref>[http://science.energy.gov/funding-opportunities/award-search/ DOE Grant Funding]</ref>

{{Infobox University |name = Zeppelin Universität |image = ZU-Logo.svg |image_size = 240px |caption = [[Seal (device)|Logo]] of Zeppelin University |motto = ''Zwischen Wirtschaft, Kultur und Politik'' |mottoeng = Bridging Business, Culture and Politics |established = 2003 |type = [[Private university|Private]] – [[Research university|Research]] |affiliation = |endowment = |president = Prof. Dr. Insa Sjurts |head_label = |head = |faculty = |staff = 217 |students = 1300 |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |other = |city = [[Friedrichshafen]] |state = [[Baden-Württemberg]] |province = |country = [[Germany]] |coor = |campus = ''Lake Campus'', [[Friedrichshafen|FN]]
''ZF Campus'', FN
''Capital Campus'', [[Berlin]] |former_names = |free_label = Professors |free = 47 |sports = |colors = Red, white |nickname = |mascot = |athletics = |affiliations = |website = [http://www.zu.de/index_eng.php www.zu.de] |logo = |footnotes = }} [[File:Zeppelin Universität-2450.jpg|thumb|Zeppelin University (''LakeCampus'')]] [[File:ZF Campus.jpg|thumb|''ZF Campus'']] '''Zeppelin University''' (German: ''Zeppelin Universität'', '''ZU''') is a small and highly selective{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/unispiegel/studium/zeppelin-universitaet-ist-bekannt-fuer-ihr-hartes-auswahlverfahren-a-875602.html|title=Zeppelin Universität ist bekannt für ihr hartes Auswahlverfahren|author=((SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany))|date=17 April 2013|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE|accessdate=21 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.zu.de/mediathek/video/2014/imagefilm-pioneers-wanted-auswahltag.php|title=Mediathek|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2015}} private [[research university]] located at [[Lake Constance]] in [[Friedrichshafen]], [[Germany]]. It is named after the German general and airship constructor [[Ferdinand Graf von Zeppelin]], whose foundation is the main financier of Zeppelin University.Regarding the official status, see [http://www.hochschulkompass.de/kompass/xml/download/hs_liste.txt ''Hochschulrektorenkonferenz, Hochschulkompass''] (German) The university was established in 2003 and is known for its [[avant-garde]] character as well as for a sophisticated selection. On 10. September 2011, ZU was being bestowed the right to award [[doctorate]] and [[habilitation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hs-kompass2.de/kompass/xml/akkr/80540_17594_de.htm|title=Akkreditierte Studiengänge - Zentrale Datenbank|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2015}} This comes along with the right to use the title "university" (German: ''Universität''). == Overview == Zeppelin University has the legal form of a non-profit, limited liability organization and calls itself "university bridging business, culture and politics". Thus it stresses the multi-disciplinary character of research and teaching that is an integral part of its self-image. The university is accredited nationally by the Academic Council of the Federal Republic of Germany ([[Wissenschaftsrat]]). The undergraduate major courses are accredited by ACQUIN, a German higher education accreditation agency. Zeppelin University has two main campuses in [[Friedrichshafen]]: One right on the banks of [[Lake Constance]] (the ''LakeCampus'' or ''SMH'') and the nearby ''ZFCampus'' (or ''FAB3''), which was built from 2013 to 2015 to create more space for the quickly growing university. Both campuses are modern, designed by well-known architects, and contain [[classroom]]s, [[lecture hall]]s, offices, [[cafeteria]]s, a [[library]] and a wing free to use solely by students. From 2007 to 2008 (until the closure of the airport), Zeppelin University had an additional location in the foyer of [[Tempelhof International Airport]] in Berlin, the so-called “Institute for the Art of Swimming on Air”. Since 2011, there is a campus in Berlin again (''CapitalCampus''). There are several [[student group]]s and projects, such as groups affiliated with political parties (''LHG, Jusos, RCDS''), a debating club (''Soapbox''), the Club of International Politics (''CIP''),{{Cite web|url=http://www.international-politics.org/|title=CIP|website=CIP|access-date=2017-06-07}} a Model United Nations group (MUN), which also organizes ''LakeMun'', entrepreneurial groups, a cultural club which also organizes a music festival at the university (''SeeKult''), a student medical service, a filming group, several bands and many more - some of them are even known nationwide (e.g. ''RockYourLife''). In 2008, the student radio station ''Welle20'' went on air.https://www.zu.de/studium-weiterbildung/das-studium/studentische-projekte.php ==Selection== Applicants are selected by the university in an arduous two-step selection process: after a detailed written application, in which the first selection is made, the most auspicious candidates will be invited to an [[assessment centre|assessment day]] (''Pioneers Wanted''). Thereby, the candidates undergo a program consisting of several interviews with professors, students, [[alumni]], and external reviewers, as well as written tests. Furthermore, they have to accomplish a realistic project which is introduced by an associated organisation, whereby a problem has to be solved as a group and must be presented afterwards in front of the assessment committee.ZU: [https://www.zu.de/studium-weiterbildung/bewerbung-bachelor/bewerbung.php Application] The selection procedure of ZU is being considered as outstandingly sophisticated, also because of its deviating modalities compared to other universities: ZU deliberately refrain from the solely use of a [[numerus clausus]] (which is widely prevalent in German educational landscape), but instead tries to find personalities which - besides accomplishing the required performance - also fit to the university's character. Therefore, the university currently has an undergraduate acceptance rate, which is lower than 10% and a graduate acceptance rate of about 16%.{{cite web|url=http://www.zeppelin-university.de/deutsch/zeppelinuniversity/facts_figures.php?navid=8|title=zu in zahlen|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2015}} ==Courses== Students can graduate with the academic degree of a [[Bachelor of Arts]] (B.A. with 240 [[European Credit Transfer and Accumulation System|ECTS]]) and a consecutive, as well as a non-consecutive, [[Master of Arts]] or [[Master of Science]] (M.A. / M.Sc. with 120 ECTS). The university offers Bachelor courses in the field of [[Liberal arts education]]. Programs of Study are offered in: * B.A. [[Sociology]], [[Political Science|Politics]] and [[Economics]] (SPE) * B.A. [[Business administration|Corporate Management]] & [[Economics]] (CME) * B.A. [[Communication Science|Communication]] & [[Cultural studies|Cultural Management]] (CCM) and * B.A. [[Political Science|Politics]], [[Public administration|Administration]] & [[International Relations]] (PAIR).ZU: [https://www.zu.de/studium-weiterbildung/ba-studium.php Bachelor-Programme] There are Master programs in: * M.Sc. Corporate Management & Economics (CME) * M.A. General Management (GEMA) * M.A. Pioneering in Arts, Media & the Creative Industries (AMC) and * M.A. Politics, Administration & International Relations (PAIR).ZU: [https://www.zu.de/studium-weiterbildung/ma-studium.php Master-Programme] Furthermore, the university offers several Executive Master programs (E.M.A.) in: * E.M.A. Family Entrepreneurship (FESH) * E.M.A. Digital Pioneering (DIP) and * E.M.A. Business & Leadership for Engineers and Mobility Innovations (BEL).ZU: [https://www.zu.de/studium-weiterbildung/weiterbildung/index.php?navid=880908880908 Weiterbildungs-Programme] The [[tuition]] for the bachelor program amounts to 3,950.00 euro per semester or 675.00 euro per month, for the master programs from 4,000.00 euro to 4,900.00 euro per semester.ZU: [http://www.zu.de/deutsch/bewerberportal/bachelor/2010/gebuehren_BA_CME.php Tuition] There are numerous merit-based [[scholarship]]s by foundations and patrons as well as a student loan of ''[[Sparkasse]] Bodensee'' that is offered at a relatively low interest rate and is used by more than half of the students.''[http://www.brandeins.de/archiv/2005/freiheit/am-strand-der-guten-hoffnung.html Am Strand der guten Hoffnung]'', in: [[brand eins]], January 2005 Starting from Fall Semester 2011, Zeppelin University reorganized all of their undergraduate degree programmes, converting them into 4-year programs. The additional year is intended to be used as "Humboldt-year", a one-year research project at one of the partner universities. Accordingly, it has cooperation agreements for example with [[University of California]], Berkeley, with [[Sciences Po]] in Paris, with [[Copenhagen Business School]] as well as with [[Goldsmiths College]], London.ZU: [http://www.zu.de/deutsch/bewerberportal/bachelor/ZU_Bachelorbroschuere_05_2011.pdf Info-brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130217023856/http://www.zu.de/deutsch/bewerberportal/bachelor/ZU_Bachelorbroschuere_05_2011.pdf |date=February 17, 2013 }} ==Rankings== Zeppelin University is a small and exclusive private university and offers fewer programs than traditional universities in Germany. Due to its young age and small size, it typically goes unranked in international comparisons. Nevertheless, it has reached remarkable results in German Rankings: In the magazine ''Handelsblatt Karriere'', edition 07/08 dated April 27, 2007, Zeppelin University has appeared in a university ranking for the first time. It has instantly reached eighth place with its economic program.{{cite web|url=http://idw-online.de/pages/en/news?id=206668|title=Zeppelin University unter den Top 10 der deutschen Unis|publisher=|accessdate=21 July 2015}} In the most reputable German Ranking, the ''CHE University Ranking'', which was published by ''ZEIT Studienführer'' 2014/15, the university was able to reach the first place with “Corporate Management & Economics” (CME), while [https://www.zu.de/studium-weiterbildung/pair/index.php?navid=538739538739 Politics, Administration & International Relations (PAIR)] was ranked among the three best Political Science programs. In 2011/12 the Communication & Cultural Management program was ranked first place by ''CHE''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.zu.de/universitaet/rankings.php|title=Rankings|website=www.zu.de|language=de|access-date=2017-06-07}} The Sociology, Politics, and Economics degree is not ranked, due to its multidisciplinarity. In 2014, the university was listed in an international ranking for the first time: in the ''U-Multirank'' it gained the best grade "excellent". ==Staff == [[Stephan A. Jansen]] has managed ZU since its foundation and was (age 32 at that time) thereby the youngest university president in history. Well-known professors include: [[Nico Stehr]], [[Hans Ulrich Gumbrecht]], [[Helmut Willke]], [[:de:Joachim Behnke|Joachim Behnke]], Georg Jochum, [[Richard Münch (sociologist)|Richard Münch]], [[:de:Jörn von Lucke|Jörn von Lucke]], [[Lucia A. Reisch]]. In 2016, [[Daniel Dahm]] joined ZU as vice director of the European Center for Sustainability Research. In August 2007, [[Birger Priddat]] was appointed president and managing director of the [[Witten/Herdecke University]]. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{coord|47|39|31|N|9|26|02|E|display=title|region:DE_type:edu_source:dewiki}} {{Transatlantic Policy Consortium}} {{Universities in Germany}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Universities and colleges in Baden-Württemberg]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2003]] [[Category:Political science education]] [[Category:Public administration]] [[Category:Public policy schools]] [[Category:Schools of international relations]] [[Category:Friedrichshafen]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Germany]]
